and  duplicating  the  tricks  that  bamboozled  the  scientific  ob-
servers. The remarkable feature of this case was not that a group of scientists
could be fooled by a magician, but rather that these scientists assumed that
they had the expertise necessary to decide whether a paranormal phenome-
non  had  taken  place  or  not.  After  all,  the  most  obvious  explanation  of
Geller’s  feats  was  that  he  had  somehow  cheated.  To  test  this  possibility,
